	- definition:: AI should enhance human and societal well-being by augmenting human capabilities, enriching quality of life, supporting physical and mental health, enabling meaningful work, strengthening social connections, and contributing to flourishing individuals and communities.



## Academic Context

- Brief contextual overview
  - Well-being is a multidimensional construct encompassing physical, mental, social, economic, and environmental aspects of life
  - Contemporary scholarship recognises well-being as both a personal and collective phenomenon, shaped by individual agency and broader societal structures
  - The concept has evolved beyond simple happiness metrics to include life satisfaction, purpose, resilience, and the ability to thrive in diverse contexts

- Key developments and current state
  - The academic field now integrates subjective well-being (how people feel about their lives) with objective measures (access to resources, health, education)
  - There is growing consensus that well-being is not just the absence of illness or hardship, but the presence of positive experiences and opportunities
  - Recent research highlights the importance of social connectedness, meaningful work, and environmental sustainability in shaping well-being outcomes

- Academic foundations
  - Influential frameworks include the New Economics Foundation’s Five Ways to Wellbeing, the OECD’s Guidelines on Measuring Subjective Well-being, and the WHO’s definition of well-being as a resource for daily life
  - These frameworks are widely cited in policy and practice, providing a robust foundation for both research and intervention

## Current Landscape (2025)

- Industry adoption and implementations
  - Many organisations are integrating well-being into their core strategies, recognising its impact on productivity, employee engagement, and social responsibility
  - Notable platforms include the UK’s Measures of National Well-being Dashboard, which tracks progress across 10 topic areas, and the Carnegie UK Trust’s Life in the UK 2025 report, which provides a comprehensive overview of well-being trends

- UK and North England examples where relevant
  - In Manchester, the Greater Manchester Combined Authority has launched initiatives to improve mental health and social connectedness, leveraging local partnerships and community engagement
  - Leeds City Council has implemented a well-being strategy focused on reducing inequalities and enhancing access to green spaces and community facilities
  - Newcastle and Sheffield have both invested in digital health platforms to support mental health and well-being, particularly among young people and vulnerable populations

- Technical capabilities and limitations
  - Advances in data analytics and digital health technologies have enabled more granular and real-time monitoring of well-being indicators
  - However, there are ongoing challenges in ensuring data privacy, addressing digital divides, and translating insights into actionable interventions

- Standards and frameworks
  - The UK’s Office for National Statistics (ONS) continues to refine its well-being measurement framework, aligning with international standards and best practices
  - The OECD’s Guidelines on Measuring Subjective Well-being (2025 Update) provide a comprehensive set of recommendations for researchers and policymakers

## Research & Literature

- Key academic papers and sources
  - Felton, L. (2023). *Promoting Well-being: The Role of Health, Physical Activity, and Social Interaction*. Mental Health Foundation. https://www.mentalhealth.org.uk/explore-mental-health/blogs/what-well-being-how-can-we-measure-it-and-how-can-we-support-people-improve-it
  - World Health Organization. (2023). *Promoting Well-being*. https://www.who.int/activities/promoting-well-being
  - United Nations Economic Commission for Europe. (2025). *Guidelines on Measurement of Well-being*. https://unece.org/sites/default/files/2025-06/Guidelines%20on%20measurement%20of%20well-being_2025.05.30.pdf
  - Office for National Statistics. (2025). *UK Measures of National Well-being Dashboard*. https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/wellbeing/articles/ukmeasuresofnationalwellbeing/dashboard
  - OECD. (2025). *OECD Guidelines on Measuring Subjective Well-being (2025 Update)*. https://www.oecd.org/en/publications/oecd-guidelines-on-measuring-subjective-well-being-2025-update_9203632a-en/full-report/updating-and-streamlining-oecd-recommendations-on-subjective-well-being-measurement-process-and-evidence_afa2f357.html

- Ongoing research directions
  - There is increasing interest in the intersection of well-being and technology, particularly in the context of digital health and AI
  - Researchers are also exploring the role of place-based interventions in improving well-being, with a focus on urban and rural communities
  - Longitudinal studies are being conducted to better understand the long-term impacts of well-being initiatives and policies

## UK Context

- British contributions and implementations
  - The UK has been at the forefront of well-being research and policy, with initiatives such as the Measures of National Well-being Dashboard and the Carnegie UK Trust’s Life in the UK 2025 report
  - Local authorities and community organisations are increasingly adopting well-being frameworks to guide their work, with a focus on reducing inequalities and enhancing social cohesion

- North England innovation hubs (if relevant)
  - Manchester, Leeds, Newcastle, and Sheffield are home to several innovation hubs and research centres focused on well-being, including the Manchester Institute for Health and Well-being and the Leeds Institute for Data Analytics
  - These hubs are collaborating with local authorities, universities, and community organisations to develop and evaluate well-being interventions

- Regional case studies
  - Manchester’s Well-being Strategy has led to the creation of community hubs that provide a range of services, from mental health support to skills training
  - Leeds has implemented a city-wide well-being survey to better understand the needs and experiences of its residents
  - Newcastle and Sheffield have both launched digital health platforms to support mental health and well-being, with a particular focus on young people and vulnerable populations

## Future Directions

- Emerging trends and developments
  - There is a growing emphasis on the integration of well-being into urban planning and design, with a focus on creating more inclusive and sustainable communities
  - The use of AI and data analytics is expected to play an increasingly important role in well-being research and practice, enabling more personalised and targeted interventions

- Anticipated challenges
  - Addressing the digital divide and ensuring equitable access to well-being resources remains a significant challenge
  - There is also a need to balance the benefits of technology with concerns about data privacy and the potential for surveillance

- Research priorities
  - Future research should focus on the long-term impacts of well-being interventions, the role of place-based approaches, and the integration of well-being into broader policy frameworks
